pullRequest.body:
Exp of nilpotent derivative is LieEquiv
---
This PR shows that the exponential of a nilpotent derivative is a Lie isomorphism.

This work is part of the framework:
https://github.com/orgs/leanprover-community/projects/17
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [f0cab028b6](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22607/commits/f0cab028b6efb5353656d778aee8d9710b8440d5)

Import changes exceeding 2%

| %      | File |
| -      | -    |
| +3.41% | `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.Basic` |
| +2.54% | `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.Derivation.Basic` |
| +3.10% | `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.NonUnitalNonAssocAlgebra` |
| +15.80% | `Mathlib.RingTheory.Nilpotent.Exp` |

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.RingTheory.Nilpotent.Exp | 829 | 960 | +131 (+15.80%) |
| Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.Basic | 734 | 759 | +25 (+3.41%) |
| Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.NonUnitalNonAssocAlgebra | 773 | 797 | +24 (+3.10%) |
| Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.Derivation.Basic | 1219 | 1250 | +31 (+2.54%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
|<details><summary>3 files</summary> `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.Derivation.Killing` `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.Weights.Killing` `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.Weights.RootSystem`</details>|2|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.NonUnitalNonAssocAlgebra`|24|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.Basic`|25|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.Derivation.AdjointAction`|29|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.Derivation.Basic`|31|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Nilpotent.Exp`|131|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ LieRing.toNonUnitalNonAssocRing`
`+ commute_exp_left_of_commute`
`+ exp_eq_sum`
`+ exp_mul_of_derivation`
`+ exp_nilpotent_derivation`
`+ instance : NonUnitalNonAssocRing (CommutatorRing L) := LieRing.toNonUnitalNonAssocRing L`
`+ isNilpotent_lTensor_of_isNilpotent`
`+ isNilpotent_rTensor_of_isNilpotent`
`+ lTensor_exp`
`+ lie_sum`
`+ rTensor_exp`
`+ sum_lie`
`+ sum_lie_sum`
`- exp_eq_truncated`
`- instance : NonUnitalNonAssocRing (CommutatorRing L)`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I had a look at the main proof and I think it is true more generally. To be precise I think we should first add the following in the file `Mathlib.RingTheory.Nilpotent.Exp`:
```lean
theorem exp_mul_of_derivation (R B : Type*) [CommRing R] [NonUnitalNonAssocRing B] [Module R B]
    [Module ℚ B] [Algebra ℚ R] [IsScalarTower ℚ R B]
    (D : B →ₗ[R] B) (h_der : ∀ x y, D (x * y) = (D x) * y + x * D y)
    (h_nil : IsNilpotent D) (x y : B) :
    exp D (x * y) = (exp D x) * (exp D y) := by
  sorry
```
(you can then apply this in the Lie algebra setting using the `let _i := LieRing.toNonUnitalNonAssocRing L` trick)

I thought about this some more and I think I can see how to factor the proof of `exp_mul_of_derivation` through `exp_add_of_commute` (and thus save a lot of work). The idea is to work in the ring $B \otimes B$.

Given a derivation $D \in End(B)$ define $D_L = D \otimes 1 \in End(B \otimes B)$ and $D_R = 1 \otimes D \in End(B \otimes B)$. Let $m : B \otimes B \to B$ be the multiplication and note that:

- $D_L$ and $D_R$ commute
- $m((D_L + D_R) (a \otimes b)) = D(ab)$ because $D$ is a derivation

Then calculate:
$e^D (ab) = m(e^{D_L + D_R} (a \otimes b)) = m(e^{D_L} e^{D_R} (a \otimes b)) = m(e^{D_L} a \otimes e^{D_R} b)) = (e^D a)(e^D b)$.

I had a few moments over lunch so I've sketched the above idea in Lean.

Working in `Mathlib.RingTheory.Nilpotent.Exp`, if you add the imports
```lean
import Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.Basic
import Mathlib.RingTheory.TensorProduct.Basic
```
then the idea is as follows:
```lean
open scoped TensorProduct

theorem exp_mul_of_derivation (R B : Type*) [CommRing R] [NonUnitalNonAssocRing B]
    [Module R B] [SMulCommClass R B B] [IsScalarTower R B B]
    [Module ℚ B] [Algebra ℚ R] [IsScalarTower ℚ R B]
    (D : B →ₗ[R] B) (h_der : ∀ x y, D (x * y) = (D x) * y + x * D y)
    (h_nil : IsNilpotent D) (x y : B) :
    exp D (x * y) = (exp D x) * (exp D y) := by
  let DL : Module.End R (B ⊗[R] B) := D.lTensor B
  let DR : Module.End R (B ⊗[R] B) := D.rTensor B
  have h_nilL : IsNilpotent DL := sorry
  have h_nilR : IsNilpotent DR := sorry
  have h_comm : Commute DL DR := by ext; simp [DL, DR]
  let m : B ⊗[R] B →ₗ[R] B := TensorProduct.lift <| LinearMap.mul R B
  have hm (x y : B) : m (x ⊗ₜ[R] y) = x * y := rfl
  have h₁ : exp D (x * y) = m (exp (DL + DR) (x ⊗ₜ[R] y)) := by
    sorry
  have h₂ : (exp D).lTensor B = exp DL := sorry
  have h₃ : (exp D).rTensor B = exp DR := sorry
  rw [h₁, exp_add_of_commute h_comm h_nilL h_nilR, ← h₂, ← h₃]
  simp [hm]
```
Thanks for doing this: I'll have more time to do a thorough review tomorrow.
I've commented on the design issue; I'll review the proof of `exp_nilpotent_derivation` tomorrow.

Minor golf:
```suggestion
variable (L) in
/-- It is sometimes useful to regard a `LieRing` as a `NonUnitalNonAssocRing`. -/
def LieRing.toNonUnitalNonAssocRing : NonUnitalNonAssocRing L :=
  { mul := Bracket.bracket
    left_distrib := lie_add
    right_distrib := add_lie
    zero_mul := zero_lie
    mul_zero := lie_zero }

variable {ι κ : Type*}

theorem sum_lie (s : Finset ι) (f : ι → L) (a : L) : ⁅∑ i ∈ s, f i, a⁆ = ∑ i ∈ s, ⁅f i, a⁆ :=
  let _i := LieRing.toNonUnitalNonAssocRing L
  s.sum_mul f a

theorem lie_sum (s : Finset ι) (f : ι → L) (a : L) : ⁅a, ∑ i ∈ s, f i⁆ = ∑ i ∈ s, ⁅a, f i⁆ :=
  let _i := LieRing.toNonUnitalNonAssocRing L
  s.mul_sum f a

theorem sum_lie_sum {κ : Type*} (s : Finset ι) (t : Finset κ) (f : ι → L) (g : κ → L) :
    ⁅(∑ i ∈ s, f i), ∑ j ∈ t, g j⁆ = ∑ i ∈ s, ∑ j ∈ t, ⁅f i, g j⁆ :=
  let _i := LieRing.toNonUnitalNonAssocRing L
  s.sum_mul_sum t f g
```
Now that this is available here, please also use it to tidy the [corresponding instance](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/c4b2238007ba8149bdb84b8fe2159a52445f944d/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/NonUnitalNonAssocAlgebra.lean#L48) in the file `Mathlib.Algebra.Lie.NonUnitalNonAssocAlgebra`  as follows:
```diff
- instance : NonUnitalNonAssocRing (CommutatorRing L) :=
-   show NonUnitalNonAssocRing L from
-     { (inferInstance : AddCommGroup L) with
-       mul := Bracket.bracket
-       left_distrib := lie_add
-       right_distrib := add_lie
-       zero_mul := zero_lie
-       mul_zero := lie_zero }
+ instance : NonUnitalNonAssocRing (CommutatorRing L) := LieRing.toNonUnitalNonAssocRing L
```
Fixed, thx!

Because this is a definition, by using `LieAlgebra.RestrictScalars.lieAlgebra ℚ R L` you are creating a term which contains `LieAlgebra.RestrictScalars.lieAlgebra ℚ R L`. This is undesirable because it makes it more specific than it should be. For example any lemmas about this definition will have to refer to `LieAlgebra.RestrictScalars.lieAlgebra ℚ R L` since this is embedded in the term (you can actually see if you use `#print exp_nilpotent_derivation` and dig sufficiently deep).

To solve this we should generalise over the `ℚ`-Lie algebra structure by making it an input like this:
```suggestion
noncomputable def exp_nilpotent_derivation [LieAlgebra ℚ L] (h : IsNilpotent D.toLinearMap) :
    LieEquiv R L L := by
```

Implemention-wise this is now good, however I admit it is a slightly unsatisfactory mathematically since the `ℚ`-Lie algebra structure is uniquely-determined (i.e., propositionally, not definitionally). I propose that we just accept this, at least for now. For one thing it will only affect _statements_ that actually mention `exp_nilpotent_derivation`: any _proofs_ which use it internally can just conjure up the instance internally (e.g., using `LieAlgebra.RestrictScalars.lieAlgebra ℚ R L`).

The way to avoid the `[LieAlgebra ℚ L]` entirely would be what @jcommelin suggested on Zulip: use the junk-value pattern to extend `IsNilpotent.exp` to any ring by using `Ring.inverse` (if we did this we would then also write API to show that it equals the expected formula when there is actually an algebra structure over `ℚ`).

Thank you for your comment. I checked the definition using
```
set_option pp.all true
#print exp_nilpotent_derivation
```
and I see that `RestrictScalars` appears in the printed output. 

What I don’t understand is how this actually causes a problem. The following definition and statement compile just fine (even in another lean file like Derivation/Killing.lean):

```
section Call

variable (R L : Type*) [LieRing L] [Field R] [CharZero R] [LieAlgebra R L] (D : LieDerivation R L L)

noncomputable def def_call (h : IsNilpotent D.toLinearMap) : LieEquiv R L L := by
  exact exp_nilpotent_derivation D h

-- For demo purposes only, the statement is not true.
lemma lemma_call (h : IsNilpotent D.toLinearMap) : exp_nilpotent_derivation D h ≠ 1 := sorry

end Call
```

So I feel like I’m missing something important.
In any case, I’m happy to adjust the approach—whether by using `[LieAlgebra ℚ L]` or the `Ring.inverse` method in `IsNilpotent.exp`—if we decide to go that route.

I was concerned about the potential for two non-defeq `[LieAlgebra ℚ L]` structures coexisting. Here is an example of how this could happen:
```lean
example (R L : Type*) [Field R] [CharZero R]
    [LieRing L] [LieAlgebra R L] [LieAlgebra ℚ L]
    (D : LieDerivation R L L) (hD : IsNilpotent D.toLinearMap) :
    exp_nilpotent_derivation D hD = IsNilpotent.exp D.toLinearMap := by
  ext x
  dsimp [exp_nilpotent_derivation]
  -- Inspect the goal here; it looks like it should be true by definition and yet:
  rfl -- Fails! This can be proved but it is not true by definition
```
The point is that this `example` makes a statement about any `[LieAlgebra ℚ L]` structure. Moreover, the RHS of the goal picks up this typeclass variable. However the LHS is using `LieAlgebra.RestrictScalars.lieAlgebra ℚ R L` because this is hard-coded into `exp_nilpotent_derivation`. These will be mathematically equal but they are not definitionally equal: indeed we know nothing about the _definition_ of `[LieAlgebra ℚ L]` since it's an input. For the record, here is how you could close that goal:
```lean
example (R L : Type*) [Field R] [CharZero R]
    [LieRing L] [LieAlgebra R L] [LieAlgebra ℚ L]
    (D : LieDerivation R L L) (hD : IsNilpotent D.toLinearMap) :
    exp_nilpotent_derivation D hD = IsNilpotent.exp D.toLinearMap := by
  ext x
  dsimp [exp_nilpotent_derivation]
  convert rfl
  -- Now we can see the issue: `convert` highlights the two instances.
  -- The proof from here should be a one-liner but we have missing API. We should add a
  -- `Subsingleton` instance for `LieAlgebra ℚ L` analogous to `subsingleton_rat_module`.
  ext q y -- I had to add missing `@[ext]` to the definition of `LieAlgebra` for this to work
  exact map_rat_smul (_instM₂ := (LieAlgebra.RestrictScalars.lieAlgebra ℚ R L).toModule)
    (AddMonoidHom.id L) q y
```

Having said all that, this is a somewhat contrived situation and it is not a fatal design flaw to have a hard-coded instance as you have proposed: it will just make certain situations a bit awkward. One could argue that the only plausible way that `[LieAlgebra ℚ L]` will show up is in the case `R = ℚ` but in this case all is well since:
```lean
example [LieAlgebra ℚ L] :
    LieAlgebra.RestrictScalars.lieAlgebra ℚ ℚ L = inferInstanceAs (LieAlgebra ℚ L) :=
  rfl
```
So if you wish, I think we can keep the design as you have it.
(This conversation inspired me to add the missing API for proving uniqueness of `LieAlgebra ℚ L` structures, #22855)
I understand the concerns now, thank you very much!
These identities are no longer used in the PR, but we can probably still keep them.

pullRequest.title: feat(Algebra/Algebra/Lie): Exp of nilpotent derivative is LieEquiv

```lean

    [Module ℚ B] [Algebra ℚ R] [IsScalarTower ℚ R B]
    (D : B →ₗ[R] B) (h_der : ∀ x y, D (x * y) = (D x) * y + x * D y)

  sorry
```

```lean
open scoped TensorProduct

theorem exp_mul_of_derivation (R B : Type*) [CommRing R] [NonUnitalNonAssocRing B]
    [Module R B] [SMulCommClass R B B] [IsScalarTower R B B]
    [Module ℚ B] [Algebra ℚ R] [IsScalarTower ℚ R B]
    (D : B →ₗ[R] B) (h_der : ∀ x y, D (x * y) = (D x) * y + x * D y)

    exp D (x * y) = (exp D x) * (exp D y) := by
  let DL : Module.End R (B ⊗[R] B) := D.lTensor B
  let DR : Module.End R (B ⊗[R] B) := D.rTensor B
  have h_nilL : IsNilpotent DL := sorry
  have h_nilR : IsNilpotent DR := sorry
  have h_comm : Commute DL DR := by ext; simp [DL, DR]
  let m : B ⊗[R] B →ₗ[R] B := TensorProduct.lift <| LinearMap.mul R B

    sorry
  have h₂ : (exp D).lTensor B = exp DL := sorry
  have h₃ : (exp D).rTensor B = exp DR := sorry
  rw [h₁, exp_add_of_commute h_comm h_nilL h_nilR, ← h₂, ← h₃]
  simp [hm]
```

source.title: feat: for nilpotent derivations, exponential is multiplicative
